climbs.name: The Way Up
climbs.fa: Wezwick, Kiser, Kessler, Thomas, Hautenbach, or Pletta

content.description: This quality route unfortunately suffers from a no h-hands ledge rest in the prominent cave that splits the two difficult sections.  Begin with difficulty up an overhanging scoop just below the triangular cave.  After the rest, head left, then up on thin, sharp crimps.
content.location: This route is in the center of Cathedral Rock, and climbs just left of prow immediately left of the major, roof-capped dihedral that splits the crag.  A prominent, triangular-shaped cave sits right on the line, about 15 feet off the deck.

content.description: The line and location of the bolts allows for two variations. The quality line stays left of the bolts on the arête. This version is the 5.13, three star variation, but it is also possible to duck right to a chossy jug and cop a rest on the big ledge. This probably drops the grade to 12.d and deminishes the quality as it disrupts the flow.
content.protection: Five bolts lead to a bolted anchor.
content.location: This is the overhanging arête, just right of Bitch Slapped, on the far right side of Cathedral. You have to scramble up the slab to reach the start of the route.

content.description: Crack climb, only 5.7+ if you traverse from crack on right. Loose rock most of the way, but still a lot of fun.
content.protection: Up to a #3 camalot. chains on top

content.description: Start up Easy Air, clipping the first three bots. Mantle onto the ledge and move left to the thin crack. All the gear for the crux section can be placed from this ledge but it's really tough to do onsight and you won't be able to see the upper cams real well. Now climb straight up and finish right to the anchors of Easy Air.
content.protection: Three draws, small cams, and one 2" cam. (I used a black alien, blue alien, green alien, purple C3, green C3, and gold camalot.) You cold use fewer cams but the gear is small.

content.description: Technical moves near a bolt down low the gear the crack.  Exit left to a ledge at the larger upper roof.
content.protection: Bolts to gear.  Traverse left on the ledge to anchors.
content.location: The route just right of Mo Fo with an independent start.

content.description: Climb straight up from the ledge at the bottom then trend right to anchors.  Don't pass up protection placements.
content.protection: Generally smaller gear to a shared anchor with Faith Based Promotion.
content.location: Start a bit left of Faith Based Promotion.

content.description: Interesting stepup near the roof in the middle of the climb.  Better to traverse right to the Mo Fo anchors to descend.
content.location: The route is just left of the tree near Mo Fo.

content.description: This excellent juggy line makes for a great warm-up for the crag's more challenging lines.  With great rock and a nice position, this is a great introduction to the Pecos.  It's possible to up the ante to 10a by veering right just below the top.
content.protection: Bolts. Shares anchor with Double Roof Dilemma.
content.location: Immediately right of DRD.  Also the third bolted line from the right.

content.description: Awesome climb with an incredible roof crux.
content.protection: 5 bolts, chains at the top.. maybe 6 bolts
content.location: Starts next to giant pine tree, which is unavoidable on the rap down.

content.description: A nice trad lead although the rock could be a bit better.  Don't pass up protection opportunities and all is well.
content.location: The climb is right of the cave below Bitch Slapped.

content.description: Face climb below the roof, place a large Camalot and trend left to a rest.  Step right and up into a shallow dihedral, the crux, then continue up to a separate anchor.
content.protection: ALL gear, need a #4 Camalot for the climbing under the lower roof.
content.location: Start in the shallow dihedral left of Double Roof Dilemma.
Uphill and a little left of a shallow right facing dihedral

climbs.name: Faith Based Promotion
climbs.fa: Wezwick, Kiser, Kessler, Thomas, Hautenbach, or Pletta

content.description: This excellent line offers technical crimping on immaculate rock.  This line is devious throughout, but always seems to provide a key jug just when you need it.
content.protection: Bolts, bolted lowering anchor, shared with the routes to the left.
content.location: This route is front and center, closest to the highway.  Immediately left of The Way Up.

content.description: The holds are a little difficult to find but the technical difficult is moderate.
content.protection: Bolts (a couple of longer slings useful) to chain anchors.
content.location: The route just right of Ooze Move.

content.description: This recently bolted line, once popular as a TR, now makes for an excellent jug-hauling sport climb.  Surmounting -- you guessed it -- two roofs, this line snakes its way over excellent pink stone with many stem-rests and large holds.
content.protection: Bolts, easy to TR from Ooze Move.
content.location: Immediately right of the large dihedral (aka "Li'l Darlin'") slightly right of center.  Also the first bolted line right of The Way Up.

content.description: Interesting movement through some smaller roofs.  Do not pull off handhold near the third clip.
content.protection: Bolts, a long sling useful at third bolt.
content.location: This is the leftmost route at Cathedral Rock.  Walk uphill and left of Mo Fo.

climbs.name: [Redacted]
climbs.fa: Wezwick, Kiser, Kessler, Thomas, Hautenbach, or Pletta

content.description: Go straight up the bolt line underneath the giant roof. The face climbing is excellent, but exiting the roof/arete is the crux. Every move on the route is great. Though the crux is very pumpy.
content.location: Climb the slab on the right side of Cathedral rock up until your next to the cave. Follow the bolt line  out of the left side of the roof.

content.description:
Cathedral Rock is the main Pecos crag, and offers many of the best routes on excellent rock.  This rock faces west-ish, and so is shady in the a.m., and sunny in the p.m. 

  This crag offers a number of pure trad lines, on mossy slabs and steep, roof-y dihedrals.  However, the numerous well-bolted sport climbs are the main attraction here.
